sense.name: possessing flamboyant vigor, confidence
sense.examples: Women think that political candidate has a lot of dash and charisma. Mary's parties always have a lot of dash about them.

sense.name: a short hasty journey to a destination
sense.examples: Mary made a last-minute dash to the mall for some Christmas presents. He felt exhausted after his frantic dash to the airport.

sense.name: a sports event which is a brief foot race
sense.examples: Bob won the gold medal in the 100-yard dash. They are practicing for the 50-yard dash.

sense.name: a sudden bolt or running
sense.examples: The burglar made a dash for the door when he heard the sound. My dash to save the glass from falling to the floor did not succeed.

sense.name: punctuation mark used in writing
sense.examples: He spelled the obscene word with a few dashes replacing letters, so it looked less vulgar on the page. The playwright used a dash in the middle of the king's speech to indicate an interruption by the queen. The teacher taught them when to use dashes and when to use semicolons.

sense.name: the longer telegraphic signal of Morse Code
sense.examples: What do three dots and four dashes signify in Morse Code? A dash has longer duration than a dot in Morse Code.

sense.name: a small, additional and distinctive quantity of something
sense.examples: This soup needs just a dash of salt. His speech was punctuated throughout with dashes of humor.

sense.name: an instrument panel
sense.examples: The man hit his head hard on the dash during the collision. The lights on the dash glowed a soft green.

sense.name: musical notation as a vertical bar, indicating staccato
sense.examples: The dashes above these notes mean to play them in a staccato manner.

sense.name: a sudden hitting or striking against
sense.examples: The dash of hail against the windshield caused a large crack. The dash of the ship against the rocks was a terrible sight to behold.
